item.dc:creator: Arimyth
item.description:
akabillposters:

It’s interesting. It depends on who’s creating the ‘music video’ – i.e. whether the Auxy cover artist is providing the channel with a readymade video containing the Auxy cover, or they’re providing the channel owner with just the music and the channel owner is adding imagery to it.

From what he said, I got the impression that he would be creating the “music video”, although it’s also not improbable that he’s provided with a fully uploadable video, in which case (NightOwl) you would not need to pay royalties (in this regard, assuming your rights to upload the cover in the first place are all taken care of ).

akabillposters:

The Auxy cover artist would be the ones who need to worry about royalties owed to the original publisher.
If they’re also creating the video file (with still/moving imagery) they’d need to take care of the synch licensing too.

An option to consider might be a visualizer that (NightOwl) you can devise and render yourself to avoid complications with imagery as your visuals. It can also have a very nice effect in tandem with your audio depending on the genre.

akabillposters:

You might be right, though I think NightOwl was thinking more like a repost channel, rather than being the primary release point for Auxy covers.

Well, if that’s the case, it’ll make his life a bit easier in this regard.

Anyway, these are the subtleties you need to consider if (NightOwl) you want to make this happen. Definitely doable, just know what you’re getting yourself into.

item.title: YouTube channel - Auxy remakes
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Arimyth:

The point of considering the audience he has access to with his youtube project is to weigh the time and effort as well as the royalty aspect of his endeavor relative to the payout

It’s interesting. It depends on who’s creating the ‘music video’ – i.e. whether the Auxy cover artist is providing the channel with a readymade video containing the Auxy cover, or they’re providing the channel owner with just the music and the channel owner is adding imagery to it.

The one who adds imagery/video is the one who should be getting the synch licensing.

If the Auxy artist is providing the video file, the only royalties the channel owner would need to worry about are those owed to the Auxy cover artist, as they’re merely reposting a new original synched recording. However, we’d assume that the Auxy cover artist would waive those royalties due from the channel owner.

(Of course, one option would be for the Auxy cover artist to register their creation with the Content ID system, so that any revenue generated on YT from that music video would be redirected back to themselves.)

The Auxy cover artist would be the ones who need to worry about royalties owed to the original publisher.
If they’re also creating the video file (with still/moving imagery) they’d need to take care of the synch licensing too.

 
Although, as mentioned in the CDBaby FAQ article, many don’t which is why the Content ID system and automated claims on monetisation are typically used to handle things on YT now.

Note: Content ID is based on recordings, not published words and music, per se.
but, if a cover is very close to the original recording, it’s possible that it could be incorrectly identified as that original recording and an automated claim issued.

It’s complex and messy, for sure.

 

it did strike me that the latter is what he was considering rather than a purely reposting channel

You might be right, though I think NightOwl was thinking more like a repost channel, rather than being the primary release point for Auxy covers.

 

@blakkaz
Fwiw, Landr Distribution now includes cover versions.

Distrokid also makes releasing covers relatively painless – as well as submission to YT’s Content ID system c/o their ‘YouTube Money’ option.

(I have a 3-artist plan with Distrokid, but I’m curious to try releasing under some of the others too including Landr and Amuse.)

item.title: YouTube channel - Auxy remakes
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Arimyth:

Those distributing commercially (via distribution services like Amuse for example) would not be the best candidates to try to duck out of royalties for.

For sure, but as mentioned, even publicly posting on SC or YT (and possibly even here, as it’s a public forum) qualifies as a commercial release, as the Auxy artist is potentially able to benefit commercially, either directly from monetisation, or indirectly, by advertising the (Auxy) artist.

Whether or not the (Auxy) cover is likely to actually generate revenue has no bearing on its classification as a commercial release.

 

tightly knit is largely referring to the fact that at in the best case scenario his project would reach maybe 25-75 people

Similarly, the number of people it might realistically reach, despite being publicly available, isn’t really relevant.
If it’s publicly available, then it’s technically released.
If it’s not offered as non-for-profit (e.g. released into public domain), then it’s a commercial release.

 

which might not justify the royalties he’d have to pay on a per track basis. However, that’s for NightOwl to decide.

It would be for the Auxy artist themselves to pay the royalties, not @NightOwl as the reposting channel owner.
(Unless NightOwl is considering a label/releasing agent/distributor arrangement, which is unlikely.)

 
All that said, the CDBaby/DIY Musician post linked earlier does a fairly good job of explaining what would actually happen for cover versions released without royalties – i.e. YT’s Content ID algo might identify it, and the publisher would automatically take any monetisation.
(Check out the section on ‘Synch licensing’.)

 
One thing I’m not clear about is what happens when YT’s Content ID algo identifies a cover track that does have a synch license and royalties paid up.
In those situations, the publisher wouldn’t have the right to take the monetisation. I would assume the cover artist would need to counter-claim and show that they’ve got those things sorted.

item.description:
akabillposters:

As I understand it, it’s more common for publishers* to give carte blanche permission to create cover versions.
i.e. they give broad, open permission. You just need to pay the royalties.

These days, you don’t typically need to contact the publisher. Just register your cover version, pay the royalty fees (see above) and you’re good to go.

It’s uncommon for publishers to block a cover artist.

(* it’s the publishers who own the rights, though they are sometimes also the recording/release artist, but not always.)

True. However, for such a small project operating in a tightly knit community, I assume he doesn’t think it’s worth it to pay royalties in which case you can obtain explicit clearance from the original producer to cover it without the need of royalties.

Are you and those who want to have their covers/remakes posted prepared to pay the royalties?

It’s not huge sums - e.g. Distrokid costs it at ~$12 per cover per year.
But still, many here can’t/won’t pay for something like Soundcloud Pro account, so I’m not sure how many will offer up covers for the channel.

 

Arimyth:

Depending on how the creator of the original track licensed their song (and if they did it properly), covers aren’t allowed without permission from the creator

As I understand it, it’s more common for publishers* to give carte blanche permission to create cover versions.
i.e. they give broad, open permission. You just need to pay the royalties.

These days, you don’t typically need to contact the publisher. Just register your cover version, pay the royalty fees (see above) and you’re good to go.
